newsitem.title: UK: Moody's says may cut Turkey's sovereign ratings.
newsitem.headline: Moody's says may cut Turkey's sovereign ratings.

text.p: Turkey's sovereign credit ratings may be downgraded because of the country's deteriorating fiscal situation, international credit agency Moody's Investors Service said on Thursday.

Moody's said in a statement it put Turkey's Ba3 long-term foreign currency sovereign ceiling for bonds on review for possible downgrade, as well as the B1 foreign currency sovereign ceiling for bank deposits.
Moody's said the the move related both to the poor fiscal situation and the apparent inability of the authorities to remedy structural ills in the budget deficit.

"The public sector borrowing requirement was estimated to have exceeded 10 percent of GDP in 1996. It appears that excessive fiscal stimulus has contributed to an overheating of the economy which, in turn, has resulted in a substantial widening of the current account deficit," the agency said.
There was a risk higher inflation could destabilise financial markets and complicate the government's debt servicing position.
"While the government's renewed commitment to privatisation was encouraging, official estimates of revenues from the programme appeared optimistic," Moody's said.
